text: [Music]
[Music]
[Applause]
the Highline uh is an old elevated rail
line that runs for a mile and a half
right through Manhattan and it was
originally a freight line that ran down
10th Avenue and it became known as death
Avenue because so many people were run
over by the trains that the railroad
hired a guy on Horseback to run in front
and he became known as the Westside
Cowboy but even with the cowboy about
one person uh a month was killed and run
over so they elevated it they built it
30 feet in the air right through the
middle of the city but with the rise of
Interstate Trucking it was used less and
less and by 1980 the last train Road it
was a train load of frozen turkeys they
say at Thanksgiving from the meat
packing district and then it was
abandoned and I live in the neighborhood
and I first read about it in the New
York Times in an article said that said
it was going to be uh demolished and I
assumed someone was working to preserve
it or save it and I could volunteer but
realized no one was doing anything um I
went to my first community board meeting
which I'd never been to one before and
sat next to another guy named Joshua
David uh who was a travel writer and at
the end of the meeting we realized we
were the only two people that were sort
of interested in the project most people
wanted to tear it down
so we exchanged business cards and we
kept calling each other and decided to
start this organization Friends of the
Highline and the goal um at first was
just saving it from Demolition but then
we also wanted to figure out what we
could do with it and what first
attracted me or interested me was this
this view from the street which is this
you know steel structure sort of Rusty
this industrial Relic but when I went up
on top it was a mile and a half of
Wildflower running right through the
middle of Manhattan you know with views
of the Empire State Building and the
Statue of Liberty in the Hudson River
and that's really where we started the
idea of coest around let's make this a
park and let's have it be sort of
inspired by this uh wildscape at the
time there was a lot of opposition mayor
Giuliani wanted to tear it down I'm
going to fast forward through a lot of
lawsuits and a lot of sort of community
engagement um Mayor Bloomberg came in
office he was very supportive but we
still had to make the e e omic case you
know this was after 911 the city was in
tough times so we commissioned an
economic feasibility study to try to
make the case and it turns out we got
those numbers wrong we thought it would
cost $ hundred million to build so far
it's cost about 150 million and the the
main case was this is going to make good
economic sense for the city so we said
over a 20-year time period the value to
the city and increased property values
and increased taxes would be about 250
million that was enough it really got
the city behind it it turns out we were
wrong on that now people estimate it's
created about a half a billion dollars
or will create about a half a billion
dollars uh in tax revenues for the city
we did a design competition selected a
design team we worked with them to
really create a design that was inspired
by that sort of wildscape there's three
sections we opened the first section in
2009 it's been sort of successful beyond
our dreams last year we had about 2
million people which is about 10 times
what we ever estimated this is one of my
favorite features in section one it's
this Amphitheater right over 10th Avenue
and the first section ends at 20th
Street right now the other thing it's
generated obviously a lot of economic
value it's also inspired I think a lot
of great architectures there's a point
where you can stand here and see
buildings by Frank Gary Jean Nel shago
Bond Neil dinari and the Whitney is
moving downtown and is building a their
new Museum right at the base of the
Highline and this has been designed by
Renzo Piano and they're going to break
ground in May and we've already started
construction on section two this is one
of my favorite features this fly over
where you're 8 ft off the surface of the
Highline running through a canopy of
trees the Highline used to be covered in
Billboards and so we've sort of taken a
playful take where instead of framing
advertisement it's going to frame people
and views of the city this was just
installed last month and then the last
section was going to go around the Rail
Yards which is the largest undeveloped
site in Manhattan and the city has plann
for better for worse a 12 million square
feet of development that The High Line
is going to ring around but you know
what really I think makes the Highline
special is the people and honestly even
though I love the designs that we were
building I was always frightened that I
wouldn't really love it because I fell
in love with that wildscape and how
could you recreate that magic but what I
found is it it's in the people and how
they use it that to me makes it so
special and just one quick example is I
realized right after we opened that
there were all these people holding
hands on the Highline and I realized New
Yorkers don't hold hands um we just
don't do that in outside but you see
that happening on the Highline and I
think that's you know the power that
that public space can have to transform
how people experience their city um and
interact with each other thanks
w
[Music]
